definition: lit. like the sun at noon (idiom)/fig. to be at the peak of one's power, career etc
as/as if/such as
abbr. for 日本[Ri4 ben3], Japan
sun/day/date, day of the month
to hit (the mark)/to be hit by/to suffer/to win (a prize, a lottery)
within/among/in/middle/center/while (doing sth)/during/(dialect) OK/all right
China/Chinese/surname Zhong
day/sky/heaven
becoming more prosperous with each passing day
flushed with success/proud of one's success (in exams, promotion etc)/as pleased as punch
to stand firmly/to gain a foothold/to establish oneself
summit/apex/pinnacle (of one's career etc)/peak (of a civilization etc)
to go downhill/to decline/to slump
to hit the big time
internal trouble and outside aggression (idiom); in a mess both domestically and abroad
rivers pour away by the day (idiom); going from bad to worse/deteriorating day by day
lit. to drop a thousand zhang in one fall (idiom)/fig. (of business, popularity etc) to suffer a sudden, devastating decline/to take a dive
lit. late-comer lives above (idiom); the up-and-coming youngster outstrips the older generation/the pupil surpasses the master
to make one's name/to become famous
to reveal outstanding talent (idiom); to stand out as conspicuously brilliant
to advance boldly/to push ahead vigorously

to come first in triennial palace examinations (idiom, refers to the carved stone turtle head in front of the imperial palace, next to which the most successful candidate in the imperial examinations was entitled to stand)/to be the champion/to be the very best in any field
flourishing period/golden age
an up-and-coming youngster/new talent/a brilliant younger generation
